text.text: We're excited to be hosting you in the Shortcuts and Siri channel this week! You can find the full schedule of Q&As for Shortcuts and Siri by visiting the <https://apps.apple.com/us/app/apple-developer/id640199958 | Apple Developer app> and <https://developer.apple.com/events/ask-apple/questions-and-answers/ | website>.
If you haven’t already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=vpbyzfg4 | how Q&As will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone — developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/events/policy/online-event-attendance-policy/ | attendance policy>.

messages.text: <@U03V30M0C1K> added a workflow to this channel: *Ask Apple - shortcuts-and-sirikit*.

elements.text: added a workflow to this channel:
Ask Apple - shortcuts-and-sirikit

messages.text:
*Let's talk about App Shortcuts, App Intents, SiriKit, and more!*
For the next hour we've got a great cross-functional team of Engineers here to answer all your questions around App Shortcuts, App Intents, SiriKit, and everything related. Use the :heavy_plus_sign: button to kick off the workflow. And don't hesitate to follow-up in discussion using the threads that are created. We're looking forward to a lively conversation. :tada:

elements.text: Let's talk about App Shortcuts, App Intents, SiriKit, and more!
For the next hour we've got a great cross-functional team of Engineers here to answer all your questions around App Shortcuts, App Intents, SiriKit, and everything related. Use the
button to kick off the workflow. And don't hesitate to follow-up in discussion using the threads that are created. We're looking forward to a lively conversation.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Will you answer the questions posted in the last few hours or just the new questions that come in now?

elements.text: Will you answer the questions posted in the last few hours or just the new questions that come in now?

elements.text: same question as above… i posted several questions on Monday… wondering if those will be entertained

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We're working through them in the order they came in regardless of when they were asked... so YES. Discussions coming shortly

elements.text: We're working through them in the order they came in regardless of when they were asked... so YES. Discussions coming shortly

messages.text:
<@U045NGKNMPH> asked
> When creating an AppIntent, is it possible to limit a date parameter to a certain date range?  I would like to be able to use something similar to the `supportsNegativeNumbers` and `inclusiveRange` options we can give to Measurement and Int parameters respectively, but can't find anything in the documentation.
> 
> I am currently checking the date within the `perform` method, and throwing an error if it is outwith the range I require, but it would be nice to do this validation prior to running the shortcut.
> 
> Thanks very much for creating this new framework – I've had great fun upgrading my SiriKit intents and taking advantage of the new features!

elements.text: asked

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Awesome idea! We've thought about that. What's your use case? Would love to hear about it so we can keep that in mind.

elements.text: Awesome idea! We've thought about that. What's your use case? Would love to hear about it so we can keep that in mind.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Just to chime in, an example where we would use such feature is scheduling a reminder, which should only accept dates in the future

elements.text: Just to chime in, an example where we would use such feature is scheduling a reminder, which should only accept dates in the future

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If you write up a feedback, it would be great if you could post it here. We can then make sure it is followed up on.

elements.text: If you write up a feedback, it would be great if you could post it here. We can then make sure it is followed up on.

messages.text:
<@U04656DU0BX> asked
> I've developed an App Intent that works great on the iPhone and now I want to be able to target the HomePod.  How do we do that?  I haven't seen any specific documentation around this, but I do remember a WWDC video that mentioned App Intents would work with HomePod. Thank you for your help!

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I've developed an App Intent that works great on the iPhone and now I want to be able to target the HomePod.  How do we do that?  I haven't seen any specific documentation around this, but I do remember a WWDC video that mentioned App Intents would work with HomePod. Thank you for your help!"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Glad to hear that it' working great on the phone and thank you for your interest in HomePod! App shortcuts on the HomePod isn't available yet and will be coming later this year!

elements.text: Glad to hear that it' working great on the phone and thank you for your interest in HomePod! App shortcuts on the HomePod isn't available yet and will be coming later this year!

Thanks!"}]}

messages.text:
<@U0464MKLKPW> asked
> When using App Shortcuts, the automatically created shortcuts are only accessible on the iPhone. There is currently no way of running the shortcuts, via Siri, on the HomePod or the Apple Watch. Was this intentional?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"When using App Shortcuts, the automatically created shortcuts are only accessible on the iPhone. There is currently no way of running the shortcuts, via Siri, on the HomePod or the Apple Watch. Was this intentional?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you for your interest in App Shortcuts on other platforms! Currently Siri support for App Shortcuts is not available yet on Watch and HomePod. It will be coming later this year.

elements.text: Thank you for your interest in App Shortcuts on other platforms! Currently Siri support for App Shortcuts is not available yet on Watch and HomePod. It will be coming later this year.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: ah! didnt realize Watch support was later this year too!

elements.text: ah! didnt realize Watch support was later this year too!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yay! Thank You <@U045WHLKDF0>!

elements.text: Yay! Thank You

messages.text:
<@U0464MKLKPW> asked
> Phrases for App Shortcuts need to be spoken precisely. There is no room for error. i.e. the system fails to recognize nuances such as "What is..." and "What's..." requiring the user to say the phrase exactly how the developer specified it, which can lead to a frustrating experience. Given the user may not always speak the phrase verbatim, the system should be smart enough to accept phrases with small insignificant variances in the language, or ask the user to confirm.

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Phrases for App Shortcuts need to be spoken precisely. There is no room for error. i.e. the system fails to recognize nuances such as \"What is...\" and \"What's...\" requiring the user to say the phrase exactly how the developer specified it, which can lead to a frustrating experience. Given the user may not always speak the phrase verbatim, the system should be smart enough to accept phrases with small insignificant variances in the language, or ask the user to confirm."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
With App Shortcuts, your app provides a set of phrases. The user does have to say these phrases exactly, but you can provide as many phrases as you would like. We would suggest thinking about all of the ways the user might want to say your shortcut phrase, and include all of them as phrases in your App Shortcut definition.

Thank you for the feedback on enabling the system to understand phrase variations automatically! Would it be possible to file a feedback report with some examples of what phrases you would like the system to understand automatically?

elements.text:
With App Shortcuts, your app provides a set of phrases. The user does have to say these phrases exactly, but you can provide as many phrases as you would like. We would suggest thinking about all of the ways the user might want to say your shortcut phrase, and include all of them as phrases in your App Shortcut definition.

Thank you for the feedback on enabling the system to understand phrase variations automatically! Would it be possible to file a feedback report with some examples of what phrases you would like the system to understand automatically?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for the response <@U04636190N6>! i will absolutely file a feedback on this and include examples. Siri, more often than not, can understand minor variations in spoken requests, but with App Shortcuts i noticed it can be less forgiving. That said, our customers are loving this feature in our Apps!

elements.text: Thanks for the response

! i will absolutely file a feedback on this and include examples. Siri, more often than not, can understand minor variations in spoken requests, but with App Shortcuts i noticed it can be less forgiving. That said, our customers are loving this feature in our Apps!

elements.text: Thank you! If you write up a feedback, it would be great if you could post it here. We can then make sure it is followed up on.

messages.text:
<@U0464Q0CQAX> asked
> Whats the current recommended way to implement media intents in an app? Should we be looking at App Intents and is it even possible to implement play media intents using App Intents or do we need to use intent definition files and handlers?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Whats the current recommended way to implement media intents in an app? Should we be looking at App Intents and is it even possible to implement play media intents using App Intents or do we need to use intent definition files and handlers?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: SiriKit Media Intents should be used for media playback use cases.

elements.text: SiriKit Media Intents should be used for media playback use cases.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Thanks, <@U044GAPEAG2>!
So <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appintents/audiostartingintent|AudioStartingIntent> is not meant as a replacement for the SiriKit Play Media Intent?

elements.text: Thanks,

!
So
AudioStartingIntent
is not meant as a replacement for the SiriKit Play Media Intent?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: AudioStartingIntent is *not* a replacement for SiriKit INPlayMediaIntent.

elements.text: AudioStartingIntent is
not
a replacement for SiriKit INPlayMediaIntent.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks

elements.text: Thanks

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If you want a good Siri (voice) experience for playing media content, SiriKit Media Intents are the right ones to use. If you want to create a Shortcut with audio playing in it, then you may use AudioStartingIntent.

elements.text: If you want a good Siri (voice) experience for playing media content, SiriKit Media Intents are the right ones to use. If you want to create a Shortcut with audio playing in it, then you may use AudioStartingIntent.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Awesome, thanks - so in general, aim for SiriKit Media Intents for (real) playback controls and use AudioStartingIntent for anything .. less significant? Looking for the right phrase there..

elements.text: Awesome, thanks - so in general, aim for SiriKit Media Intents for (real) playback controls and use AudioStartingIntent for anything .. less significant? Looking for the right phrase there..

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Use SiriKit Media Intents for voice experience, i.e. when a user asks to play something from a media app. You can use AudioStartingIntent if you need to build any automation in Shortcuts, e.g., start playing news at x time every day.

elements.text: Use SiriKit Media Intents for voice experience, i.e. when a user asks to play something from a media app. You can use AudioStartingIntent if you need to build any automation in Shortcuts, e.g., start playing news at x time every day.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Alright, that sounds like `AudioStartingIntent` might be our solution - we are looking to build automations, and were wondering which implementation to aim for - thanks a bunch!

elements.text: Alright, that sounds like
AudioStartingIntent
might be our solution - we are looking to build automations, and were wondering which implementation to aim for - thanks a bunch!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Gotcha. You welcome.

elements.text: Gotcha. You welcome.

messages.text:
<@U04642Q4N67> asked
> Hello, I can't localize my AppShortcut. When I go to Shortcuts description continue in english when I am in spanish. Same from Siri intents...

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hello, I can't localize my AppShortcut. When I go to Shortcuts description continue in english when I am in spanish. Same from Siri intents..."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: App Shortcut phrase localizations should be included in `AppShortcuts.strings` files. Here is a helpful article <https://sowenjub.me/writes/localizing-app-shortcuts-with-app-intents/>. If you are still running into issues, can you file feedback and include a sample project?

elements.text: App Shortcut phrase localizations should be included in
AppShortcuts.strings
files. Here is a helpful article
. If you are still running into issues, can you file feedback and include a sample project?

. If you could include a sample project that would be really helpful. Please post the FB# here after so I can make sure it gets looked at!

messages.text:
<@U046S70K9A4> asked
> :v: thanks for being here!  SiriKit has been limited to the predefined domains. And now App Intents lets you expose any piece of functionality you want from your app. So it confused me to see some new protocols in the App Intents docs for super specific domains like StartDiveIntent. Why does this exist? Why wouldn’t a dive app just make its own app intent for this?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"emoji","name":"v","unicode":"270c-fe0f"},{"type":"text","text":" thanks for being here!  SiriKit has been limited to the predefined domains. And now App Intents lets you expose any piece of functionality you want from your app. So it confused me to see some new protocols in the App Intents docs for super specific domains like StartDiveIntent. Why does this exist? Why wouldn\u2019t a dive app just make its own app intent for this?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is useful for cases where we need to know what type of intent this is. For example, Apple Watch Ultra may expose Dive Apps / Intents in specific places, or behave different for them relative to other Intents which are not Dive related.

elements.text: This is useful for cases where we need to know what type of intent this is. For example, Apple Watch Ultra may expose Dive Apps / Intents in specific places, or behave different for them relative to other Intents which are not Dive related.

Many folks on the Apple Developer Forums have reported this issue but no solutions were posted. Is there a trick to getting ShortcutsLink to show the App name? Thanks

messages.text:
<@U045WVA9RKQ> asked
> A simple question, the EntityPropertyQuery implementation for my Note model object results in a "Find Note" app shortcut, while the Apple Notes app as a "Find Notes" (plural) and the Calendar app a "Find Calendar Events" (plural) shortcut, which makes more sense given it returns an array. How do I define that the plural form of my Note Entity name is used?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"A simple question, the EntityPropertyQuery implementation for my Note model object results in a \"Find Note\" app shortcut, while the Apple Notes app as a \"Find Notes\" (plural) and the Calendar app a \"Find Calendar Events\" (plural) shortcut, which makes more sense given it returns an array. How do I define that the plural form of my Note Entity name is used?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi, you need to provide `numericFormat` for your entity's `typeDisplayRepresentation` . Please see this document: <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appintents/typedisplayrepresentation/numericformat>

elements.text: Hi, you need to provide
numericFormat
for your entity's
typeDisplayRepresentation
. Please see this document:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Perfect, thanks

elements.text: Perfect, thanks

We had a rarely-used location parameter that we just removed entirely because users were confused why they needed to grant location permission for an action that wasn't doing anything with location. (FB11511578)

This happens even if no location is being passed in. Is that intentional? messages.text:
<@U046NK3MB7Y> asked
> When creating a parameter summary in an App Intent that has multiple boolean parameters that show or hide other parameters, is there a better way to account for all the possible parameter combinations other than a complex tree of nested ParameterSummaryWhenConditions?
> 
> Basically this is what I’m trying to do (I know this doesn’t actually work) where certain parameters are child parameters of another parameter and only show if the parent parameter is switched on (similar to how it works in intent definition files):
> 
> static var parameterSummary: some ParameterSummary {
>     Summary("Do the thing") {
>         \.$setParameterA
>         
>         if \.$setParameterA {
>             \.$parameterAOptions
>             \.$someOtherParameterAOption
>         }
>         
>         \.$setParameterB
>         
>         if \.$setParameterB {
>             \.$parameterBOptions
>         }
>         
>         \.$setParameterC
>         
>         if \.$setParameterC {
>             \.$parameterCOptions
>             \.$someOtherParameterCOption
>         }
>     }
> }

elements.text: asked
Hi, you can use
Switch
in addition to
When
, for example:

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Thanks for the reply. I think I’m missing something. How would Switch help to account for all the combinations in the example?

For instance if A, B, & C are all on, the summary would be:
```Summary("Do the thing") {
    \.$setParameterA
    \.$parameterAOptions
    \.$someOtherParameterAOption
    
    \.$setParameterB
    \.$parameterBOptions
    
    \.$setParameterC
    \.$parameterCOptions
    \.$someOtherParameterCOption
}```
…versus all off:
```Summary("Do the thing") {
    \.$setParameterA
    
    \.$setParameterB
    
    \.$setParameterC
}```
…versus A & C on:
```Summary("Do the thing") {
    \.$setParameterA
    \.$parameterAOptions
    \.$someOtherParameterAOption
    
    \.$setParameterB
    
    \.$setParameterC
    \.$parameterCOptions
    \.$someOtherParameterCOption
}```

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hey! When you say that you can see your intent in the Shortcuts app, do you mean the Shortcuts editor or in the library? Only App Shortcuts display in the Shortcuts library and can be triggered through Siri.

elements.text: Hey! When you say that you can see your intent in the Shortcuts app, do you mean the Shortcuts editor or in the library? Only App Shortcuts display in the Shortcuts library and can be triggered through Siri.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, I can see my app in shortcut editor only.  App doesn’t appear in  App Shortcut list. So when  App Intent is be configured properly it appears in `App Shortcuts` list?

elements.text: Yes, I can see my app in shortcut editor only.  App doesn’t appear in  App Shortcut list. So when  App Intent is be configured properly it appears in
App Shortcuts
list?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You will want to create App Shortcuts, which will associate your App Intent with a phrase that will appear in the Shortcuts library and that can be triggered using Siri. I recommend checking out this WWDC video for more details on how to implement this: <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10170/>

elements.text: You will want to create App Shortcuts, which will associate your App Intent with a phrase that will appear in the Shortcuts library and that can be triggered using Siri. I recommend checking out this WWDC video for more details on how to implement this:

messages.text:
<@U045WVA9RKQ> asked
> One suggestion, if function builders can be avoided, please do so. I think the `static var appShortcuts: [AppShortcut]` method should not use a function builder and should instead just return a standard swift array. It's a bit of a rant against function builders themselves, which I personally believe shouldn't have been added, it creates a DSL for every framework Apple ships, which has huge costs in learning curve and maintenance, but so be it and we passed the bridge I guess. But in this case it's crazy IMHO that this code is giving an error:
> 
> ```
>     static var appShortcuts: [AppShortcut] {
>         return [AppShortcut(intent: OpenOverviewIntent(),
>                         phrases: [AppShortcutPhrase("shortcuts.openOverview.siriPhrase1".localized)],
>                         systemImageName: "smallcircle.filled.circle")]
>     }
> ```
> while it's correct swift code and what anyone would expect, while this:
> 
> ```
>     static var appShortcuts: [AppShortcut] {
>         AppShortcut(intent: OpenOverviewIntent(),
>                     phrases: [AppShortcutPhrase("shortcuts.openOverview.siriPhrase1".localized)],
>                     systemImageName: "smallcircle.filled.circle")
>     }
> ```
> is upon reading invalid swift but actually what you need to provide (loose from the fact that `phrases` is then asking for a real array instead of also requiring function builders. 
> 
> So again, my request, if function builders _can_ be avoided, please do so. I now have to remember that with this particular framework, and this particular method, I shouldn't actually return an array (which is what everyone would expect given the static var tells me to) but instead _not_ return an array but some function builders. To just save typing a comma and two square brackets? Or is there more than the eye can see?

elements.text: asked

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for your feedback! In the iOS 16.1 SDK, it should be possible to define `AppShortcut`s as arrays, in addition to as result builders. Please give it a try!

elements.text: Thanks for your feedback! In the iOS 16.1 SDK, it should be possible to define
AppShortcut
s as arrays, in addition to as result builders. Please give it a try!

messages.text:
<@U0462QAUTNH> asked
> I want to create an App Shortcut with switch-like behaviour, like “Set Bluetooth On” (available on iOS), where the user can say “Set Bluetooth On” or “Toggle Bluetooth”.
> 
> To distinguish one "action" from the other when `perform()` method is called, i think that "Set" and "Toggle" should be parameters, so for the AppIntent, the code should looks something like this:
> ```
> struct ChangeLockSettingsIntent: AppIntent {
>     enum ChangeStatusOperation: String, AppEnum {
>         case set, toggle
> 
>         static var typeDisplayRepresentation: TypeDisplayRepresentation = "Operation"
>         static var caseDisplayRepresentations: [Self: DisplayRepresentation] = [
>             .toggle: "Toggle", .set: "Set"
>         ]
>     }
> 
>     @Parameter(
>         title: "Operation",
>         default: .set
>     )
>     var operation: ChangeStatusOperation?
> 
>     @Parameter(
>         title: "Lock status",
>         default: false,
>         displayName: Bool.IntentDisplayName(true: "open", false: "closed"),
>     )
>     var newStatusIsOpen: Bool?
> 
>     [ … ]
> }
> ```
> 
> How can I build an App Shourtcut like that, that allow user to say “Set bike lock open”, “Set bike lock closed” or "Toggle bike lock"?

elements.text: asked

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can create 3 different App Shortcuts here for each of your App Intent configurations. Let me know if I can help further clarify. If this doesn’t quite fit your needs, please file feedback!

elements.text: You can create 3 different App Shortcuts here for each of your App Intent configurations. Let me know if I can help further clarify. If this doesn’t quite fit your needs, please file feedback!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you for your response <@U04636190N6> . I think I need a further clarification. How can I distinguish which App Shortcut has been called?

elements.text: Thank you for your response
. I think I need a further clarification. How can I distinguish which App Shortcut has been called?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I think I just discovered (looking at <https://sowenjub.me/writes/localizing-app-shortcuts-with-app-intents/>, linked by you in one of the previous responses) that I can pass an App Intent with parameters on App Shortcut creation! :tada: :exploding_head:

elements.text: I think I just discovered (looking at
, linked by you in one of the previous responses) that I can pass an App Intent with parameters on App Shortcut creation!

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
When creating each App Shortcut, the App Intent you include can be configured for each of your states. As an example:
```AppShortcut(
    intent: ChangeLockSettingsIntent(operation: .set, newStatusIsOpen: true),
    phrases: [
        "Set bike lock open with \(.applicationName)"
    ]
)```
You would want to repeat this with an App Shortcut for closing as well as one for toggling.

elements.text: When creating each App Shortcut, the App Intent you include can be configured for each of your states. As an example:
You would want to repeat this with an App Shortcut for closing as well as one for toggling.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you! That’s fantastic!

elements.text: Thank you! That’s fantastic!

messages.text:
<@U0478BJ4UPK> asked
> I have an app with a SiriKit intent extension that handles INCreateNoteIntent. I also have a Watch app, which also has an intent extension for handling INCreateNoteIntent. Recently I switched the iOS app to use in-app intent handling, which is awesome. At first, I deleted the iOS intent extension, but then my build failed because the intents handled on the Watch’s extension must be a subset of the ones handled by the iOS app and it doesn’t seem to see my in-app intent handlers. So then I restored the iOS extension to fix the error; that builds and runs, but App Store Connect rejects it because I’m handling “duplicate” intents in my app an extension.
> 
> What’s the way out of this? And re: WatchOS, is there a way to handle SiriKit intents in-app on watchOS or is there something else I should be doing?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I have an app with a SiriKit intent extension that handles INCreateNoteIntent. I also have a Watch app, which also has an intent extension for handling INCreateNoteIntent. Recently I switched the iOS app to use in-app intent handling, which is awesome. At first, I deleted the iOS intent extension, but then my build failed because the intents handled on the Watch\u2019s extension must be a subset of the ones handled by the iOS app and it doesn\u2019t seem to see my in-app intent handlers. So then I restored the iOS extension to fix the error; that builds and runs, but App Store Connect rejects it because I\u2019m handling \u201cduplicate\u201d intents in my app an extension.\n\nWhat\u2019s the way out of this? And re: WatchOS, is there a way to handle SiriKit intents in-app on watchOS or is there something else I should be doing?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This looks like a bug on our end; it should be a supported configuration to have your app implement in-app intent handling and have the Watch extension continue working. Please file feedback and include a small sample project. Thank you!

elements.text: This looks like a bug on our end; it should be a supported configuration to have your app implement in-app intent handling and have the Watch extension continue working. Please file feedback and include a small sample project. Thank you!

messages.text:
<@U046S8WJ11T> asked
> Do you have any advice for unit testing App Intents Extension targets? There seems to be a catch-22 where Xcode can only test App Intents that are part of the application target or framework, but App Intents can’t be discovered via the extraction compile step if they are in a package or framework.

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Do you have any advice for unit testing App Intents Extension targets? There seems to be a catch-22 where Xcode can only test App Intents that are part of the application target or framework, but App Intents can\u2019t be discovered via the extraction compile step if they are in a package or framework."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can include your AppIntents Swift files in your test target that runs using XCTRunner by specifying `USES_XCTRUNNER = YES` in the build settings.

elements.text: You can include your AppIntents Swift files in your test target that runs using XCTRunner by specifying
USES_XCTRUNNER = YES
in the build settings.
